answers.author: Eric Palm
answers.text:
Allison, You raise a good question that rasies an additional issue.  
First, to answer your question, we had a similar issue when we went to 36 hour weeks (half-day Fridays).  In the instance of a holiday within a work week, we let the employees work 32 and receive 8 hour holiday pay.  We only have 10 holidays per year, and considering the additional sacrifices the employees have made for the organization, we felt this was a fair resolution.
Second, with our PW employees working four "9s" to reach their 36 in the summer, what do you do when an employee has a holiday (or other PTO) which is traditionally 8 hours and now is working a 9/10 hour days?  In this instance, we have determined that the employee will only receive the 8 hours for the holiday and they can make up the additional hour by using comp time or working an hour during the remainder of the week.
Hope this helps.

answers.author: Teresa Johnson
answers.text:
I used to work for the police department with varying shifts, however on the week of a holiday we used two methods to pay our employees. 

those in the office reverted back to 8 hour work days the week of the holiday.
those scheduled to be off on the actual holiday received holiday leave time to be used anytime within the next three months.    This information was maintained by the payroll administrator.

author: Alison Gray
text: We are setting up a 4-10 work week.  If we are working Mon thru Thru with Friday off and Friday is a pd holiday, does the employee forfeit a holiday or are they able to have another day off, similar to when a holiday falls on a Saturday or Sunday?  We need clarification on this.  Can anyone help?
title: Compressed work week
